metadata.title: Traumatic Brain Injury - Fall with Head Trauma
learning_objectives: Perform systematic GCS assessment and trending
Identify signs of rising intracranial pressure
Prevent secondary brain injury (maintain SpO2 >90%, SBP >90)
Recognize significance of anticoagulation in head injury

changelog.v3.0_enhanced: Blueprint Structure Enhancement v2 applied: matching config, clinical anchors, consequence templates, ECG standardization. Deterioration timing 5/9/13 min. Duration 20 minutes. Removed challenge_points.

dispatch_info.location: Residential home, found at bottom of stairs
dispatch_info.additional_info: Fell down stairs, hit head, confused, bleeding from head

scene_description.location: Inside home, patient at bottom of staircase (12 steps visible)
scene_description.safety: Scene safe, no ongoing hazards, stairs visible showing mechanism
scene_description.access: Ground floor, good access for stretcher
scene_description.bystanders: Wife present, very distressed, heard fall from other room

patient_profile.name: Ján
patient_profile.personality: Initially confused, minimizing injuries ('I'm fine'), becomes less responsive as time progresses

initial.student_sees: You arrive to find an elderly man sitting propped against the wall at the bottom of a staircase. There's a visible laceration on his right forehead, bleeding steadily and matting his gray hair. Blood has dripped onto his shirt. He's looking around confusedly, touching his head repeatedly. 'What... what happened?' he asks, seeming disoriented. His wife is kneeling beside him, holding a blood-soaked towel to his head. 'He was carrying laundry down the stairs and I heard a terrible crash. I think he missed a step and fell all the way down - it's 12 steps! He hit his head hard on the floor. That was maybe 10 minutes ago.' When you speak to him, he looks at you but seems confused. 'My head hurts,' he says slowly. You notice his right pupil looks slightly larger than the left.
initial.appearance: Elderly male, confused, bleeding forehead laceration, sitting position, disoriented to events, right pupil slightly larger and sluggish
initial.clinical_note: HIGH-RISK MECHANISM: Fall down 12 stairs with direct head impact. GCS 13 (E4V4M5) with unequal pupils - concerning for intracranial bleeding. ON WARFARIN - anticoagulated patient with head injury is CRITICAL. Early hypertension (165/95) and relative bradycardia (HR 68) may be early Cushing's response. IMMEDIATE C-spine precautions required. Serial GCS monitoring essential.

improving.student_sees: With your interventions, the patient appears more stable. His GCS has improved slightly - he's now answering questions more appropriately, though still confused about the fall itself. 'I'm Ján... I live here... what day is it?' He's lying supine on a backboard with C-collar, oxygen in place. The bleeding is controlled. His pupils remain unequal but stable. He's complaining of headache. His wife looks somewhat reassured.
improving.appearance: More alert than initially, GCS 14, C-spine protected, bleeding controlled, still in pain, vital signs stable
improving.clinical_note: Patient showing slight improvement with supportive care. GCS 13→14. Still concerning features (unequal pupils, amnesia, anticoagulated). Key is PREVENTION OF SECONDARY BRAIN INJURY - maintain SpO2 >90%, SBP >90. Continue serial monitoring during rapid transport to trauma center.

deteriorating.student_sees: The patient's condition is worsening. He's no longer opening his eyes spontaneously - you have to call his name loudly to get a response. When he does respond, it's with incomprehensible sounds. His right pupil is now obviously dilated - 6mm and barely reacting to light, while the left is 3mm and reactive. His blood pressure has increased to 185/105 and his heart rate has dropped to 58. His breathing has become slightly irregular. 'Ján! Open your eyes!' you call. He groans but doesn't open them. His wife is crying.
deteriorating.appearance: Decreased responsiveness, GCS 9 (E2V2M5), right pupil 6mm fixed, left 3mm reactive, Cushing's triad developing
deteriorating.clinical_note: CRITICAL DETERIORATION - classic signs of herniation syndrome. Cushing's triad (hypertension, bradycardia, irregular breathing) indicates severely elevated ICP. Right pupil dilation indicates uncal herniation with CN III compression. This is a neurosurgical emergency. Hyperventilate briefly only if herniation signs present. Rapid transport critical.

critical.student_sees: CRITICAL: The patient is now unresponsive. His right pupil is fully dilated (8mm) and fixed - no reaction to light at all. His left pupil is also becoming sluggish (4mm). He's not opening his eyes, not making sounds, and only withdrawing weakly to pain. His breathing has become irregular and slow. Blood pressure is 195/110, heart rate 50. This is herniation. His wife is screaming for you to help him.
critical.appearance: Unresponsive, GCS 5-6 (E1V1M3-4), bilateral pupil abnormalities, Cushing's triad, decerebrate posturing beginning
critical.clinical_note: Uncal herniation in progress. This patient is dying from brain compression. Without immediate neurosurgical intervention, death is imminent. Brief controlled hyperventilation (target ETCO2 30-35) may temporarily reduce ICP. This is the pre-arrest state for TBI.

breathing.initial: RR 18, regular, adequate depth, clear bilateral breath sounds
breathing.deteriorating: RR becoming irregular, Cheyne-Stokes pattern may develop

circulation.initial: HR 68 (relative bradycardia for trauma), BP 165/95 (hypertension), CRT <2sec

exposure.head: 5cm laceration right forehead actively bleeding, palpable step-off concerning for skull fracture, scalp swelling
exposure.neck: C-spine precautions - cannot clear due to altered mental status

sample_history.symptoms: Head pain, confusion, amnesia for event
sample_history.past_history: Atrial fibrillation (on warfarin), Hypertension, Prior minor stroke 3 years ago
sample_history.events: Wife: 'He was carrying laundry down, I heard crash, found him at bottom. 12 stairs. Direct head impact on floor. Maybe 10 minutes before you arrived.'

focused_exam.head: 5cm laceration right forehead, active bleeding, possible skull depression palpable, blood in hair
focused_exam.neurological: Anisocoria (pupils unequal), GCS 13, confused, moving all extremities

other_findings: Left ventricular hypertrophy pattern (from chronic hypertension)

interpretation.diagnosis: Atrial fibrillation - controlled rate, patient's known baseline
interpretation.mechanism: Pre-existing AF, explains anticoagulation with warfarin

ecg_findings.teaching_point: ECG is NOT indicated as primary assessment in TBI. Focus on neurological assessment. The AF explains why patient is on warfarin - this anticoagulation makes head injury much more dangerous. ECG confirms no cardiac cause for fall.

oxygen.indication: Prevent secondary brain injury - maintain SpO2 >94%

scenario_specific_response.teaching_point: In TBI, hypoxia (SpO2 <90%) doubles mortality. Apply oxygen if SpO2 drops below 94%.

scenario_specific_response.clinical_effect: This patient is hypertensive (165/95) so does NOT need fluids. Only give if SBP drops below 90.
scenario_specific_response.teaching_point: Goal in TBI: prevent hypotension (SBP <90). This patient is HYPERtensive - do NOT fluid overload. Maintain IV access but restrict fluids unless BP drops.

if_given.clinical_effect: No effect - glucose is normal. Time wasted.

scenario_specific_response.teaching_point: ALWAYS check glucose in altered mental status, but this patient's confusion is from HEAD INJURY, not hypoglycemia. Glucose 5.8 is normal.

5min.description: GCS dropping, confusion worsening, pupil asymmetry increasing, Cushing's reflex developing

9min.description: GCS 8 - airway protection needed, herniation signs developing, right pupil blown

13min.description: Active herniation, bilateral pupil involvement, respiratory failure imminent, near-arrest state

critical_harm.name: sedatives
critical_harm.why_dangerous: Masks neurological deterioration, makes GCS trending impossible

if_given.patient_response: Patient becomes sedated. GCS drops but is this from sedation or herniation? You can no longer tell.

critical_harm.teaching_point: NEVER sedate a TBI patient unless treating seizures. The GCS is your ONLY window into what's happening inside the skull. Sedatives fog that window.

worsens.name: morphine
worsens.why_wrong: Respiratory depression, masks neuro exam, causes miosis affecting pupil assessment

if_given.patient_response: Patient drowsy, breathing slow, pupils constricted (miotic) - can no longer assess for herniation.

worsens.teaching_point: Opioids mask neuro assessment in TWO ways: sedation masks GCS, and miosis masks pupil signs of herniation.

neutral.name: mannitol
neutral.why_prehospital_caution: May be appropriate for herniation but requires medical direction

if_given.clinical_effect: May transiently reduce ICP. Appropriate ONLY if herniation signs present.

neutral.teaching_point: Mannitol can reduce ICP in herniation but is typically hospital therapy. Follow local protocols.

critical_actions_checklist.criteria: Identifies fall from height, high-risk mechanism
Manual stabilization then collar, cannot clear C-spine with altered mental status
Check size, reactivity, symmetry both pupils
Asks about medications, identifies warfarin use
Recognizes need for trauma center with neurosurgery

common_errors.teaching_point: High-risk mechanism + altered mental status = cannot clear C-spine
common_errors.clinical_anchor: Fall from height plus confusion equals collar. Period. You can't examine what you can't trust.

common_errors.teaching_point: Serial GCS is essential - it's the trend that matters, not single value
common_errors.clinical_anchor: A GCS of 13 is information. A GCS dropping from 13 to 9 is an emergency. Trend tells the story.

common_errors.teaching_point: Anisocoria in TBI indicates lateralized mass effect - surgical emergency
common_errors.clinical_anchor: Unequal pupils in head injury means bleeding is pushing brain to one side. That's neurosurgery NOW.

common_errors.teaching_point: Anticoagulated patients have much higher bleeding risk - catastrophic in TBI
common_errors.clinical_anchor: Warfarin turns a bad head injury into a fatal one. Always ask about blood thinners.

common_errors.teaching_point: Sedation makes GCS trending impossible - you lose your only window
common_errors.clinical_anchor: Sedate a TBI patient and you're flying blind. The GCS is your only instrument.

common_errors.error: Excessive IV fluids in hypertensive patient
common_errors.teaching_point: Avoid over-resuscitation - can worsen cerebral edema
common_errors.clinical_anchor: This patient is hypertensive. More fluid means more edema means more brain swelling.

common_errors.teaching_point: Hypertension + bradycardia + irregular breathing = critically elevated ICP
common_errors.clinical_anchor: High BP, slow pulse, irregular breathing - that's the brain screaming for help.

consequence_templates.template: C-spine precautions were never applied. {patient_name} had a high-risk fall mechanism with altered mental status - you CANNOT clear the C-spine in this patient. Any movement could have caused or worsened spinal cord injury, resulting in paralysis.
consequence_templates.medical_basis: Fall from height + altered mental status = high risk for cervical spine injury. Standard of care requires immobilization.

consequence_templates.template: Initial GCS was assessed at {actual_time} minutes. Earlier GCS assessment would have established a baseline for trending. Without early baseline, you cannot detect deterioration patterns that indicate rising intracranial pressure.
consequence_templates.medical_basis: GCS trending is more important than single values. Early baseline enables detection of deterioration.

consequence_templates.template: {patient_name}'s warfarin use was never identified. Anticoagulated patients with head injury have dramatically higher mortality - the bleeding doesn't stop. This information affects treatment urgency and hospital notification.
consequence_templates.medical_basis: Warfarin-associated intracranial hemorrhage has mortality >50%. Early identification triggers reversal protocols.

critical_decision_points.description: Appropriate C-spine management in head injury

scoring.optimal: Immediate manual stabilization, applied collar early, maintained precautions throughout, verbalized cannot clear C-spine due to altered mental status.
scoring.acceptable: Applied C-spine precautions, even if slightly delayed.
scoring.dangerous: No C-spine precautions applied, or cleared spine despite altered mental status.

critical_decision_points.clinical_anchor: Can't clear the C-spine if you can't trust the exam. Altered mental status means automatic precautions.
critical_decision_points.aar_teaching_point: C-spine clearance requires a reliable exam - patient must be alert, oriented, not intoxicated, no distracting injuries. This patient is confused with amnesia - you CANNOT clear the C-spine clinically. Maintain precautions.

scoring.optimal: Documented GCS at arrival with full breakdown, repeated at least once, identified any change in trend.
scoring.acceptable: Performed initial and follow-up GCS assessment.
scoring.dangerous: No formal GCS assessment or gave sedatives making assessment impossible.

critical_decision_points.clinical_anchor: One GCS is a snapshot. Serial GCS is a movie. The movie shows you if the brain is bleeding.
critical_decision_points.aar_teaching_point: GCS trending is THE key assessment in TBI. A stable GCS 13 is concerning but manageable. A GCS dropping from 13 to 9 over 10 minutes is catastrophic. Always document baseline and reassess frequently.

scoring.optimal: Verbalized targets (SpO2 >90%, SBP >90), monitored continuously, had oxygen ready, recognized patient is currently HYPERtensive so doesn't need fluids.
scoring.suboptimal: Allowed periods of hypoxia or didn't monitor.
scoring.dangerous: Significant hypoxia or hypotension occurred without intervention, or over-resuscitated hypertensive patient.

critical_decision_points.clinical_anchor: In TBI, hypoxia and hypotension each double mortality. Both together? Catastrophic. Prevent them.
critical_decision_points.aar_teaching_point: Primary brain injury happened at impact - you can't fix that. Secondary brain injury (hypoxia, hypotension) is PREVENTABLE. Goals: SpO2 >90% (ideally 94-98%), SBP >90mmHg (ideally >110). This patient is hypertensive - don't over-resuscitate.

key_concepts: GCS trending more important than single values
Anisocoria = lateralized mass effect = surgical emergency
clinical_pearls: Cannot clear C-spine with altered mental status
Relative bradycardia in trauma patient is concerning (should be tachycardic)
Warfarin patient with head injury needs urgent CT and possible reversal
Never sedate TBI patient unless treating seizures
